ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: This class covered really important information, but honestly, it just went way too fast to be comprehendible. To adequately cover this material, I think Financial Concepts should be offered as a real, full semester 2-3 credit course. There is just no way for people with no background in financing (which represented the majority of the class) to gain anything valuable from the current setup because you are just constantly trying to play catch up and Prof. Burke just goes way too fast (because she has to). I wanted to like this class, but I just couldn't because I didn't get what I wanted out of the class.

In short, this class attempts to cover too much material in too short of a time frame. This is perhaps unsurprisingly - and also not necessarily overly problematic. I don't expect to get a deep understanding of financial management in 12 hours; but it does provide a brief introduction and allows you to become familiar with the language and concepts. It is geared toward for-profit companies and I will likely never need to do the calculations we did in this class as I intend to work in the non-profit sector. However, it gives me the language acumen and background to start to position myself to oversee the budgets of projects and organizations.

This course is REALLY useful for people without any financial background. Yes it moves quickly and is a little painful, but it is worth it to know how to read a balance sheet and understand finance-speak.
I found that the pace of this class went a bit too quickly. I understand that this class is a PSC but could this class be offered as a full semester 3 credit class?

This course was very helpful and should be made into a full semester course so we can learn more about the concepts introduced, as well as other financial skills that are relevant to all FES students.

I think that the biggest challenge this course faces is teaching enough material in such a short time. The result was a really rushed course with out time for examples or clear explanations. I think the pace was too fast: there were too many brand new concepts that all built on each other - I never felt like I had time to digest what was being taught before moving on to the next topic. As a result I did not absorb very much.
These skills will be applicable for any future employment.
I wonder if this course could lose a section of materials that is covered, in order to cover less over a longer period of time in order to slow things down a week.

Finance is not easy for me, so I was very impressed that Maureen was able to teach me so much in just a few weeks. Her class materials are extremely thorough; she clearly works hard (and successfully) to make the subject accessible.
Great job putting the material for this class together.

I thought the pace was a tad too quick and the presentations are loaded with so much information that you invariably have to reference them when doing the homework. That speaks to the usefulness of the materials, but also to the dizzying amount of information crammed into 6 or 7 class sessions. 80% of the material tought in this short-course is going to be very valuable to MEM degree-holders. This course deserves to be spread out over a semester and kept about the same level of intensity throughout. If it's all about repitition, repitition, repitition; why not give people the chance to practice over an entire semester?

This topic was clearly very much in demand, and I thought it was a critical offering at F&ES. So many other courses we're taking (well, especially cross-listed with SOM) reference the kinds of concepts that were taught here. Maureen did a good job translating this stuff, and the examples (Good Fish, for instance) were very helpful.

Its just a tough course to teach. A ton of material covered in a very short amount of time. Very top level, which means it is hard to retian anything as a student. Maureen did as good a job as one can do though and the assignments were helpful.

I had a proactive study group that met on the weekends to discuss the material and do the homework. But, we still struggled because the material was so dense and we were unable to fully grasp the concepts in class.
Maureen is wonderful and goes out of her way to learn the names of students - impressive in such a large class.
Very useful if quick overview of financial concepts.
The homework - that's really where I learned the material
These are critically fundamental tools for any professional to learn. Should be mandatory, or better yet incorporated into an early crash course/ MODS
I learned some of the vocabulary that finance experts use and how to begin to understand financial statements.

The course itself was great. Maureen does a nice job of explaining these concepts to beginners in the field. In addition, it was great to have the class at night. The class was informal, and the in-class exercises were helpful for learning the material.
The homework really helped to solidify concepts taught in class. The posted lecture notes were also very comprehensive and easy to follow.
The use of actual examples. For example, it was great to see an example of how a wind turbine was financed.

The very clear explanations, and the extensive guidance for home works, which were carefully written such that completing them was not onerous, while at the same time, thorough understanding of the material was required
Very concise presentation of the most important and useful infos.
Maureen did a great job of providing clear and easily to follow notes and slides.
The course materials (powerpoints and outlines) were very detailed and provide great references for applying the lessons of the class in the future.
The introduction it provided to financial analysis, which is useful for anyone really.
Just being exposed to some of the language and basic concepts that we will see throughout our careers.
To get familiarity with the technical terms.
learning how to use excel (at least a little bit) and the basics of financial terminology and assessments
Introduction to financial concepts
Learning applied skills
Learning about how corporations approach financial management and evaluation of company values/stock.
The problem sets were very helpful and reinforcing. Also Maureen's lecture notes were very helpful in making sure that you understood the course material before doing the homework.
Doing the homeworks in teams was incredibly beneficial, and even fun.
the quick feedback on the homework at the beginning of class.
Maureen took lot of personal interest.
Very detailed and thorough examination of the basics
How approachable the material was and the professor's ability to teach it.

Cracking the codes of finance speak. I actually had taken a few classes prior to this PSC that required I do a lot of googling and wikipedia-ing to keep pace, and so this "intro" class actually helped me gel a lot of what I self-taught in fits and bursts. Learning what the strict definitions of various financial terms was = also helpful.
The Homeworks reenforced the lessons.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Needs. More. Time. Period.
The evening time slot is tough but realistically unavoidable.

I appreciate that Maureen tries to give us more understanding of the financial sector than she then tests in the homework, but I wish the notes went into more depth on the most important things instead. I would have rather had to do a supplemental reading about how the stock market works, for example, and devoted the extra class time to the homework concepts.
The amount of material that is covered - too much for 6 classes
It can be hard to follow the instructor during class; there's a lot of material that, while clearly organized, wasn't always explained clearly.

Some of the harder concepts needed to be broken down and explained with a little more time. It seemed that the pace and difficulty of the concepts covered was very steep and the easy concepts that we talked about in the beginning of class could have been addressed with less time so that there would be more time to talk about the more challenging concepts in later classes.

I think there are some other financial management skills that would be really useful for environmental managers. While some of us will end up working in the corporate sector, seek investors for business start-ups, and/or interpret financial statements, many more of us will go on to manage work groups or NGOs that have to deal with budgeting for grants and/or dealing with fund accounting and projects to determine funding surplus/gaps for staffing.
The pace.
It needs to be made longer to go deeper into some of these concepts and address other related concepts.
Cannot think of anything - would like to know the material more I depth, but time did not allow
Minor critique - the ppt slides could be designed in more of a standard format (more reader friendly) as they would be useful as printouts/notes.

This course needs to be offered over a longer period of time. Six classes is not enough time for this material. In general, more finance classes should be offered. MEM students shouldn't need an MBA in order to understand basic finance concepts. This class is a start but due to compressed nature, it falls just short.
Perhaps the timing? I understand that scheduling is an issue but dealing with large numbers at the end of the day is not very conducive to learning.
Moves a bit too quickly and tries to cover too much ground for a 1-credit course. Might work better to focus on fewer topics and cover them more in depth.
a bit too much work for one credit, at least compared to other 1 unit classes
Should be earlier in the semester.

The first two classes progressed very well and then I felt like we were speeding through material and I wasn't fully understanding everything I did before starting the homework. I think the course should be more than 6 weeks. It is not a course suitable for the professional skills courses. It should be an actual 3-credit course.
Hmmm the powerpoints are still a little bit dense.
More homework to drill the concepts into my brain! Also could have moved faster/covered more content.
the pace and length of the course. also, the homeworks are a tad bit meticulous.
No complaints. I do think maybe add another TA for such a big class, though.

It is a difficult problem but it is hard for me to imagine doing any financial analysis after this course. I guess it is good exposure but perhaps eliminating some of the lectures and spreading out the others might be a good idea. This 1 unit course could easily be two courses. One could be taught in the fall, one in the spring.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: The instructor was generally good. At times it was a little confusing and we moved super fast though.
Both very responsive!
Contacted both and both were helpful
TA answered my questions on one homework in a timely and helpful manner.
Both were extremely knowledgable and willing to help. Both the instructor and the TA responded quickly to questions. Excellent!
Excellent.
They both seemed to be available, but I did not need to reach out to them.
Absolutely excellent
very responsive and helpful
Although I did not take advantage of the TA's office hours, she was readily available.
excellent on both ends
Great!
great!
The instructor and TA were great. Both were available and clearly had the interests of the students in mind.
Great help. The TA was always available
Good.
They were very helpful.
Later in the semester, a project for another class required I dive into some specific financial markets. Maureen made a lot of time to answer emails and sit down with me, which was invaluable.
The Ta was available and good at explaining.
Excellent TA help, I never contacted the professor but she made a point to learn names when handing back homework and I appreciated that
Instructor took lot of personal interest in making it more understandable
The TA was very helpful and approachable, though it was tough to fight for her attention in just a few hours/week.
Both were great and available.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I took it to give myself that familiarity with financial concepts to be able to position myself as having some baseline knowledge and capacity to handle some such considerations professionally
Critically important to have knowledge of these basic concepts& skills
Helped fill out my schedule. I would like to take some SOM classes before I graduate, to get a sense for how business people work and think, so this was a good way to dip my toes in.
As a student pursuing the business and environment curriculum track, this course has really helped me gain skills I know I'll need in my future career.
This is an essential class for any FES student. I am focusing on energy and plan to use many of these tools for my summer internship.
The course is a good way to learn some important financial concepts and apply them in a short period of time.
It really rounded out my learning, especially since I am a business and the environment major.
This was an elective I wanted to take to increase my fluency in the language of accounting and finance.
Some added knowledge that I think would help with corporate engagement.

I think this course has important material for everyone at FES and in any type of graduate professional skill. I do think it is not designed to be a 1-credit course. The material in this course is very useful and important for professionals to understand.
I think more courses like this should be offered at F&ES. to be a good environmental manager it is really important to understand the way money is managed.
Yes accounting financial issues are one of the most important management issue of every organization

My first introduction to accounting and balance sheet management. I've managed budgets before, but in very rudimentary ways. This is a great and indespensible subject matter for young environmental businesspersons. It deserves more attention.
Joint with SOM and starting on that side next year, I think this course will prove helpful in giving me a primer before I dive in deeper.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To get a basic knowledge - mostly just to become familiar; I will take the printed out notes with meand be able to learn more practically as needed to fit my professional responsibilities in the non-profit sector
To get exposure to finance
Understanding how businesses value investments is vital for justifying environmentally-beneficial projects
Helped fill out my schedule. I would like to take some SOM classes before I graduate, to get a sense for how business people work and think, so this was a good way to dip my toes in.
I lacked skills in financial analysis and I knew that this course would teach me such skills.
I needed to learn about many of the financial tools used in the energy industry.
Wanted a fundamental understanding of the bookkeeping, putting together a business plan, and financial analysis.
To review and get used to financial concepts.
To understand financial concepts more. I have no previous finance background.

I wanted a basic familiarity of financial analysis, projections, and valuations to be able to better understand news stories as well as understand balance sheets and other documents I may incur as an environmental professional.
To augment my need for financial knowledge
This was an elective I wanted to take to increase my fluency in the language of accounting and finance.
Wanted to gain a basic understanding of financial concepts w/ out taking a class at SOM
I knew that it would be a useful skill to have. I have no background in finance and thought that this would be a good introduction.
To have some understanding of how corporations think about finances.
For a solid understanding of financial concepts that will come up in my professional career.
I'll never be the one in charge of finances in a given business setting. But now, I'm really glad to know more about how the pieces fit together and how to ask better questions of the experts.
I wanted to refresh my financial knowledge
To gain skills and exposure to vocabulary that many of us use interchangeably and incorrectly.
I wanted exposure to the financial concepts tool box.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes
Yes
Yes
Yes. It was a good overview of financial concepts!
Yes and no. It was a high quality class. But maybe not exactly what many FESers need. See answer to question 13.
Yes. Great class for somebody with no experience in the field to get a basic introduction to the concepts and vocabulary.
Yes.
Yes, I learned a lot in the short time.
Absolutely
Completely.
Yes and no. I have the notes which I can look back on but the course was rushed.
The class did meet my expectations.
Absolutely!
My expectations were met.
yes.
Yes!
Yes
It was ok.
It definitely did although there are some subject materials we covered toward the end of the class that I don't think I fully grasped due to time constraints.
Yep!
yes
Yes
Yes and No. The material was great, but it was hard to digest everything in a meaninful way.
Yes.
Not quite. It was hard to retain so much information.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: I didn't quite come away with as strong a knowledge as I hoped, in part because we covered so much material so quickly and also because I had competing time-drains that limited my investment in the class
Yes, although I will probably forget most of it if I don't use it
Yes, the course taught a broad range of applicable material.
Yes
Yes
See answer to question 13.

Yes. I do not expect to have to use the information provided in this class in my professional work, but I very much appreciate being exposed to the concepts and vocabulary of the field. In addition, the materials provided by Maureen are excellent and will be a great reference to have around in the future in case I ever need a reminder about the concepts.
Yes.
Yes
Yes
Yes
Yes, and the class reference materials will continue to be helpful.
Yes.
Yes, i did
Yes
Yes.
Yep.
yes
yes it was good experience.
Yes and no. Same answer was above.
Yes.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Doing the homework in groups is HELPFUL
The group work was not mandated but we had an informal study group that made doing and understanding the hw much easier.
Working with others really helps in better understanding the material and distinguishing among the different tools available.
My group provided helpful cross-checking of responses andmade the task of poring over spreadsheets more social and fun.
It helped to work through the homework as a group - many minds are stronger than one.
Invaluable to draw on friends' expertise and confidence with Excel to do the homeworks together. And more fun!
there were no work groups.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do your homework in a group. Read the lecture notes before class. Go to class.
It is a great course for getting a general understanding of financial concepts issues.
Read the notes she posts on classesv2. They are more useful and easier to follow than the lectures.
Do the homework while the material is fresh in your head, ie right after class or the following day.
Lecture attendance is essential.
Start the homework early and ask for help!
Work with a group for the problem sets.
Put in extra time to read the review material that professor Burke provides that consolidate the powerpoints
This course is a light addition to your curriculum and definitely very valuable.
This course needsa siginificant amount of attention if you want to fully comprehend all the concepts in the short time period.
Start the problem sets early in the week so you can reach out to the instructor, TA, or a classmate with questions.
Read up on the notes prior to class. It especially helps with the financial concepts.
Be aware that you won't learn enough to make any accounting. However, you will familiarize yourself with the technical terms.
Do the in class exercises
Stay on top of the homework assignments. They are useful. For those without experience with Excel, this course is helpful.
Pay attention during lectures and it will be easier.
Not the world's most fun way to spend your Tuesday evenings, but entirely worth it.
invest time in reading before you do the homework.
They should attend to the exercises on priority
Sit down and really wrestle with the homework, and know that if you make errors or don't get something, it will be run through at the beginning of the subsequent class.
